header.title: The Scroll of Set
header.category: Western Esotericism, Modern Satanism, Setianism, Ritual Magic

central_thesis: The article 'Psychic Hazards & Proper Use of Ritual Magic' reframes common 'psychic hazards' in magic (e.g., summoning uncontrolled forces, possession) as internal psychological phenomena rather than external threats. It posits that these arise from repressed subconscious desires and Judaeo-Christian conditioning. The Setian approach to magic, in contrast, emphasizes rational awareness, self-reliance, and the deliberate manipulation of internal forces for personal evolution and self-deification, eschewing external worship or dependence.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Book of Coming Forth by Night: Background Material
structure_content.summary: This article, by Michael A. Aquino V°, is noted as part of a closing series on 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night,' with reference to 'The Ruby Tablet of Set' for the most current edition. The content of the article itself is not provided in this issue.

structure_content.chapter_title: Aleister Crowley and the Book of the Law
structure_content.summary: This article, by Michael A. Aquino V°, discusses Aleister Crowley and 'The Book of the Law,' with reference to 'The Ruby Tablet of Set' for the most current edition. The content of the article itself is not provided in this issue.
The editor expresses gratitude to the members of Bubastis Pylon for their assistance in mailing out 'The Scroll'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Psychic Hazards & Proper Use of Ritual Magic
structure_content.summary: L. Dale Seago IV° analyzes the concept of 'psychic hazards' in magic, arguing they are internal psychological manifestations rather than external entities. He attributes these to repressed subconscious desires and Judaeo-Christian conditioning. The Setian perspective is introduced as a rational, self-reliant approach where 'powers' are internal and magic is a tool for personal evolution and self-deification, viewing Set as a mentor rather than a deity to be worshipped.

Editor's notes on the conclusion of the 'Book of Coming Forth by Night' series, references to other Setian publications (e.g., 'Voice of the Dragon'), encouragement for members (I° or II°) to ask questions of III°+ officials, and an explanation of the editorial policy for 'The Scroll of Set' regarding content submission and its purpose as a general interest platform rather than an ego-trip.

key_concepts.definition: Not external forces (uncontrolled entities, possession) but internal psychological manifestations (e.g., twisted monsters, dæmons) arising from repressed subconscious desires and Judaeo-Christian conditioning.
A magical orientation based on a dualistic 'good' vs. 'evil' principle, leading to the repression of natural feelings and desires, contributing to psychological hazards.
A subconscious solution to unresolved personal problems or conflicts, or a means of seeking attention/recognition, rather than external demonic control.

Not a 'reverse Jehovah' or object of blind worship, but a finite intelligence, guide, and mentor for an individual's self-deification and the full awareness of their own Will. Set's gift is knowledge and intelligence.
Symbolic representations of aspects of one's own personality, used as 'psychological props' in ritual to stimulate emotional force for magical workings, rather than independent external beings.

The state of a Setian who has achieved full awareness of the power of their own Will, having no need to ask favors of the Prince of Darkness, and demonstrating this knowledge in all aspects of their existence.

practical_system.description: The Setian practical system, or Setian ritual magic, is an internally-focused path for self-evolution and self-deification. It operates on the premise that all 'powers' and 'dangers' (e.g., 'dæmons') originate within the individual's subconscious personality. Magic is a tool for developing the individual Will and achieving personal goals by consciously releasing and controlling these internal forces. The aim is to unify the conscious and subconscious, strengthening the entire personality, and developing new abilities, concentration, and Will, ultimately leading to becoming a 'divine being in one's own right.' It explicitly rejects worship of external deities, viewing Set as a mentor for self-knowledge.
tools: Names of various 'demons' (from myth-cycles or invented)
The practitioner's own Will, mind, and subconscious personality (as the primary 'tools' and 'forces' being manipulated).
rituals: Deliberate release of forces from the Dæmonic or subconscious personality under controlled conditions.
Utilized as 'psychological props' and 'controlled, constructive fantasy' to stimulate emotional force for 'real objective ends'.
Not intended to influence external entities (including Set), but rather to unify and strengthen the practitioner's personality, developing their abilities, concentration, and Will.
Become less necessary as one achieves higher evolutionary levels, but gain deeper symbolic meaning.

relevant_quotes.text: How often when I was living in the desert, in the vast solitude which gives to hermits a savage dwelling ... how often did I fancy myself among the pleasures of Rome! ... When I had no companions but scorpions and wild beasts, I found myself among bevies of girls. My face was pale and my frame chilled with fasting, yet my mind was burning with desire and the fires of lust kept bubbling up before me when my flesh was as good as dead.

Indeed, the entire history of the Middle Ages is a case in point, as G. Rattray Taylor so well points out: In the earlier part of the Middle Ages what we chiefly find is frank sensuality, with which the church at first battles in vain. Then, as it improves its systems of control, we find a mounting toll of perversion and neurosis.

The Setian finds an allegorical inspiration in this and feels he can do no less if he is to be worthy of the title. The Dark Lord having infused man with knowledge and intelligence, which is what separates man from the natural order (the Biblical account, though a myth, is at least correct in that respect), man now has the key to turn the universal inertia to his amusement and make of the Universe his playground: to become, in short, a divine being in his own right.

The practice of Setian ritual magic, in a nutshell, involves the deliberate release of forces from the Dæmonic or subconscious personality under conditions which are controlled by the magician. This has two principal effects on the practitioner: first, instead of driving a wedge between the conscious and subconscious and setting them against each other, it causes them to work together, unifying and strengthening the entire personality. This in turn results in the development in the practitioner of abilities, powers of concentration, and forms of will completely unknown to him before.
Ritual magic procedures are a tool for the magician's personal use, which he can employ as a means of learning to focus his will and accomplish his goals.

He realizes that he has no need to ask favors of the Prince of Darkness, for he now knows - and demonstrates in every aspect of his existence - that the greatest gift of Set has already been bestowed upon him: the full awareness of the power of his own Will. Such a Setian has become Elect.

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is foundational to understanding the Temple of Set's core philosophy and magical methodology, particularly its departure from traditional occult and Judaeo-Christian paradigms. It establishes a psychological-materialist framework for magic, explaining 'dangers' as internal phenomena and advocating for self-reliance and self-deification. This text is crucial for contextualizing modern Setianism within the broader history of Western Esotericism and modern Satanism, showcasing a distinct rationalist and individualized approach.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience is members and prospective members of the Temple of Set, especially those at the I° or II° grades. It also targets individuals exploring alternative magical paths who seek a rationalist, psychological explanation for occult phenomena and a system focused on personal empowerment and self-evolution, rather than external worship or adherence to traditional moral frameworks.
